abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Avian Influenza Control
            and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project for the
            Kyrgyz Republic Latvia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: a global template and coordination with
            specialized agencies can enable rapid, good project design.
            The GPAI (Global Program for Avian Influenza and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response) was in place and was
            used as the basis for the preparation of this project. The
            existence of a sound, global plan ensures that an effective
            project can be formulated rapidly. WHO (World Health
            Organization) and CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and
            Prevention) gave technical assurance for project
            implementation by working together with the World
            Bank's implementing partners and agencies. This lesson
            will be applicable to a wide range of projects, not just
            those in the health sector. In the context of weak
            governance and institutions, where the capacity building may
            take a longer and concerted effort, it is important to have
            step-by-step approach, to ensure higher effectiveness and
            chances of sustainability of achievements. The project
            started off by building the legal framework and
            institutional capacity for addressing possible Avian
            Influenza emergencies. However, minor subsequent adjustments
            then allowed the project to easily initiate work on other
            priority zoo-noses, which allowed for a complex approach to
            addressing major animal and human health threats. Further
            work, building on the achievements of this project, is
            implemented by Agricultural Investment and Services Project
            (AISP), with animal vaccinations and other more practical
            applications of the Avian Influenza (AI) project results. In
            addition to the long-term investments supported by the
            project, it is necessary to ensure financing for additional
            operating costs in the future (for laboratory consumables,
            vaccines, drugs, etc.) to guarantee operation of the
            equipment and systems. In absence of an operational budget
            the sustainability of the financed equipment is
            significantly diminished. It is necessary to agree on a
            budget allocation from the government for these purposes, or
            find an alternative source of financing. A large number of
            indicators were an issue with many AI projects given the
            complexity of issues these projects were covering and the
            speed with which these projects were prepared. This project
            had original 31 indicators, which were then combined and/or
            dropped to streamline the monitoring and evaluation
            (M&E) system. However, this lead to a lot of confusion
            on the Project Implementation Unit (PIU) side, as well as
            deficiencies in the M&E system and poor monitoring of
            results on the Bank's side. Therefore, it is suggested
            to design a sound M&E system, to avoid the need for
            (sometimes several) revisions of the indicators, causing
            possible confusion.
